sen.j: 古代・中世の日本では無官の者を救済する施策として正式な制度として導入されていた。
sen.e: In ancient and medieval Japan, that baikan system was introduced as an official system to rescue courtiers without posts.

sen.j: 売官とは、任料を納めた散位の者を官職に叙任することをいう。
sen.e: Baikan meant to give a certain government post to Sani (courtier without post) who paid ninryo (fee for getting an official rank).

sen.j: 年官及び成功 (任官)などがその例である。
sen.e: Nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of the annual installation of them as government officials) and jogo (ninkan) (recruiting officials for court works and spending the money they paid for the post for the work expenses) were examples of Baikan.

sen.j: 古代・中世の日本において、六位以下の無官の者(散位)に対して救済及び任官、昇叙の機会を得させるために輪番で散位寮に出仕させた。
sen.e: In ancient and medieval Japan, the government made postless courtiers (Sani) with lower ranks than Rokui (Sixth Rank) serve for Saniryo (the office controling Sani, courtier without post) in order to help and give them chances for appointments or promotions.

sen.j: 位階昇進に必要な勤続年数を満たして任官の機会を待たせる施策がとられていた。
sen.e: The government had a policy that those courtiers would get a chance for appointments when they worked long enough for promotions.

sen.j: 次第に、これに定数ができた後も定員外の者が続労銭を納め、「労」を銭で購入する機会が提供されるようになった。
sen.e: Even after the number of posts was determined, the following chances were introduced: supernumerary courtiers bought 'labour' by paying shokurosen (money paied for getting an official rank).
